page.title: 14WILDLIFE AROUND FARLEY
page.content: There are many mammals around Farley. The largest of these are fallow deer, of which there are many. Foxes and badgers are fairly common and there are lots of rabbits and squirrels. There are many smaller mammals including harvest mice, dormice, moles and shrews. There are plenty of birds including crows, blackbirds, sparrows, robins, woodpeckers, cuckoos and house martins. As well as the usual insects there is the rare Purple Emperor butterfly, which is found in Blackmoor Copse, a nature reserve. One day in July, 1985 on a walk through Blackmoor Copse we saw these animals: pheasant, partridge, worm, black ants, red ants, mole, spider, flies, bees, butterflies, beetle, woodlice, centipede and lacewings.
